Here's the rephrased text with the noisy text removed:

Satellite data can suffer from spatial data loss. Several algorithms can reconstruct the missing parts of these images to varying degrees of accuracy, with Data Interpolating Empirical Orthogonal Functions (DINEOF) being the current standard. However, DINEOF is slow, suffers from accuracy loss in temporally homogeneous waters, relies on temporal data, and can only generate a single potential reconstruction. We propose a machine learning approach to reconstructing Chlorophyll-a data using a Variational Autoencoder (VAE). Our accuracy results to date are competitive with but slightly less accurate than DINEOF. We show the benefits of our method, including vastly decreased computation time and the ability to generate multiple potential reconstructions.

Introduction

Phytoplankton and ocean color are considered "Essential Climate Variables" for measuring and predicting climate systems and ocean health. Measuring phytoplankton and ocean color is cost-effective on a global scale and relevant to climate models. Chlorophyll-a (Chl-a) is a commonly used metric to estimate phytoplankton levels and can be derived from ocean color. Additionally, Chl-a can be used to detect harmful algae blooms, which can be fatal to marine life. As climate change progresses, harmful algae blooms will increase in frequency. An increase of 2°C in sea temperature will double the window of opportunity for Harmful Algae Blooms in the Puget Sound.

Several satellites provide Chl-a measurements, but the Sentinel-3 mission will be the focus of this paper. One of the biggest problems faced when using these measurements is the loss of spatial data due to clouds, sunglint, or other factors that can affect the atmospheric correction process. Various algorithms exist to reconstruct the missing data, with the most effective being those based on extracting Empirical Orthogonal Functions (EOF) from the data. The most accurate and commonly used of these algorithms is DINEOF, which iteratively calculates EOFs based on the input data. However, DINEOF is slow and performs poorly in more temporally homogeneous waters, such as a river mouth.

Machine learning has also been successful in reconstructing Chl-a data. A tree-based model was used to reconstruct algae in polar regions, but this method requires knowledge of the domain and is less generalizable. DINCAE is a machine learning approach that has been shown to work on Chl-a data, but it can only generate a single possible reconstruction. We propose a Variational Autoencoder (VAE) approach to reconstructing Chl-a data, which can generate multiple potential reconstructions and potentially select a better one based on additional data.

Our approach is based on the Variational Autoencoder (VAE) from Kingma et al. and Attribute2Image's improvements in making generated images less random. The dimensionality reduction in a VAE is similar to the Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) used in DINEOF. We apply a model similar to Attribute2Image and Ivanov et al.'s inpainting model to Chl-a data from the Salish Sea area surrounding Vancouver Island. We compare it to the industry standard DINEOF using experiments modeled after Hilborn et al.'s experiments. This area was chosen as it contains both areas of high and low temporal homogeneity in terms of algae concentrations, which was determined to be something DINEOF is sensitive to.

Method

The dataset we use comes from the Algae Explorer Project. This project used 1566 images taken daily from 2016-04-25 to 2020-09-30. For our experiments, we use a 250x250 pixel slice from each day to create a 1566x250x250 dataset.
